He would alternatively shift back into apologetic comments, saying: "I hope they can find in their hearts to forgive me because we had a lot of harmony going on in that home".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130806234708/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 6, 2013 |title=Ariel Castro spoke for 20 minutes in court, read what he said here |date=August 1, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=August 6, 2013 }}</ref>
The sentencing judge also heard from Knight and family members of Berry and DeJesus. Knight told Castro: "You took eleven years of my life away. I spent eleven years in hell, now your hell is just beginning. I will overcome all that has happened, but you will face hell for eternity. I will live on, you will die a little every day as you think of the eleven years of atrocities that you inflicted on us... I can forgive you, but I will never forget."<ref name=pd130801/>
==Aftermath== ===Survivors=== On July 9, 2013, Knight, Berry, and DeJesus broke their public silence for the first time since their rescue by releasing a video statement thanking the public for their support. An attorney for Berry and DeJesus said the women "still have a strong desire for privacy" and did not wish to speak to the media about their ordeal.<ref name=pd070913>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |title=New video: Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight, Cleveland's 3 missing women, thank you for your support |last1=Caniglia |first1=John |date=July 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710092111/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |title=TRANSCRIPT: Cleveland kidnapping victims say thank you for support |last1=Steer |first1=Jen |date=July 9, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711210648/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |archivedate=July 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Cleveland Courage Fund, a bank account set up to help the women in their transition to independent life, had collected approximately $1.05 million at the time of the video's release.<ref name=pd070913/> Before Berry's disappearance, her grandfather had promised to give her a classic [[Chevrolet Monte Carlo]] from the year Berry was born. He kept the car after her kidnapping, in case she was still found alive. After her rescue, Berry called her grandfather, and asked if he still had the car, which he did,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |title=Amanda Berry's grandfather keeps 1986 Monte Carlo he promised before she went missing |last1=Kiesel |first1=Connor |publisher=Newsnet5.com |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710181505/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> although it was in need of [[automotive restoration|restoration]] from having gone unused. Several automotive shops offered to perform the restoration for free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite |title=Amanda Berry and grandfather reunite |last1=Morabito |first1=Nate |publisher=WJHL |date=April 17, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801005123/http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite|archivedate=August 1, 2013}}</ref>
In an interview with [[People (magazine)|''People'' magazine]] on the first anniversary of her rescue, Knight discussed some of her ordeals as well as her life leading up to her abduction. Since her rescue, she legally changed her first name to Lily,<ref>{{cite news|last=Feran|first=Tom|title=Michelle Knight conquers her fears after 'dangling in the wind'|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|accessdate=March 16, 2015|newspaper=The Plain Dealer|date=March 14, 2015|quote=Knight has changed her own name legally to Lily[...]but she uses her better-known birth name in public appearances.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316233918/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|archivedate=March 16, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and began to get several tattoos as her way of coping with the healing process. Knight also revealed that her son was adopted by his [[foster care|foster parents]] while she was in captivity, and that while she wanted to see him, she does not want to bring him into the ordeal she has had to deal with, and planned to see him after he becomes an adult. Knight planned to open a restaurant, dreamed of getting married — which she did in 2016<ref>{{cite news|title=Michelle Knight, kept in captivity for over 10 years, reveals her marriage on "Dr. Phil"|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|work=[[CBS News]]|date=April 10, 2018|access-date=April 11, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411102025/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|archivedate=April 11, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> — and adopt children. Knight also planned to reunite with Berry and DeJesus in the future, but began focusing on getting her own life back on track.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|title=Cleveland Kidnapping Victim Michelle Knight Tells Her Story of Torture and Triumph|publisher=People.com|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=November 9, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108191416/http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|archivedate=November 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Berry and DeJesus received honorary diplomas from John Marshall High School in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|title=Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus realize high school graduation dream with John Marshall Class of 2015|newspaper=cleveland.com|access-date=January 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018015223/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===House demolition=== [[File:Seymour Avenue - panoramio.jpg|thumbnail|right|The site on Seymour Avenue in 2014.]] As part of the plea bargain, the house where Castro lived, and where he had held the women captive, was demolished on August 7, 2013. Knight was present and handed out yellow balloons, which she said represented missing children, to the gathered crowd. The balloons were released before DeJesus's aunt began the demolition with a swing of a [[crane (machine)|crane]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |title=Cleveland house of horrors destroyed — demolition crews tear down Ariel Castro's home |last1=Kemp |first1=Joe |date=August 7, 2013 |newspaper=NY Daily News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810195725/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |title=Cleveland Kidnapper Ariel Castro's 'House of Horrors' Demolished |last1=Ng |first1=Christina |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810182609/http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |title=Michelle Knight held captive for decade by Ariel Castro hands out yellow balloons on Seymour Avenue |last1=Seitz |first1=Colleen |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810222225/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Castro's death === On the evening of September 3, 2013, one month into his life sentence, Castro was found hanging with a bed sheet in his detention cell at the [[Correctional Reception Center]] in [[Orient, Ohio]].<ref name="AP suicide">{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-man-who-held-3-women-captive-found-dead |title=Cleveland man's suicide brings little sympathy |last1=Sheeran |first1=Thomas J. |last2=Welsh-Huggins |first2=Andrew |date=September 4, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131004072333/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-man-who-held-3-women-captive-found-dead |archivedate=October 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Prison staff performed [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on Castro before he was taken to the [[Wexner Medical Center at Ohio State University|Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center]] in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], where he was pronounced dead shortly thereafter.<ref name="AP suicide"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Woods|first=Jim|title=Ariel Castro dies in apparent suicide|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-commits-suicide-in-prison.html|newspaper=The Columbus Dispatch|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=September 4, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906090516/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-commits-suicide-in-prison.html|archivedate=September 6, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated9">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/justice/ariel-castro-cleveland-kidnapper-death/?hpt=hp_t1 |last1=Mungin |first1=Lateef |last2=Alsup |first2=Dave |publisher=CNN |date=September 4, 2013 |title=Ariel Castro, Cleveland kidnapper, found hanged in prison cell |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JNhFIjnY?url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/justice/ariel-castro-cleveland-kidnapper-death/?hpt=hp_t1 |archivedate=September 4, 2013 |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> The following day, [[Franklin County, Ohio|Franklin County]] [[coroner]] Dr. Jan Gorniak announced that a preliminary [[autopsy]] had found the cause of Castro's death to be suicide by hanging.<ref name="usatoday-Eversley">{{cite news|last=Eversley|first=Melanie|title=The Ohio kidnapper was not on suicide watch, but was checked on every 30 minutes by guards.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-hung-prison/2761177/|accessdate=September 4, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=September 4, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904195004/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-hung-prison/2761177/|archivedate=September 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On October 10, 2013, the [[Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction]] released a report that suggested Castro may have died accidentally from auto-[[erotic asphyxiation]] rather than suicide. Gorniak rejected the possibility, standing by her ruling of suicide. The report also said two prison guards had falsified logs documenting their observation of Castro hours before he was found dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Castro suicide report: Officers falsified reports|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|publisher=The Columbus Dispatch|accessdate=October 10, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010150554/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|archivedate=October 10, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Castro was not on [[suicide watch]] at the time of his death, but had been subject to routine checks every thirty minutes due to his notoriety.<ref name="AP suicide"/>
A consultant's report was released on December 3, and officially concluded that "all available evidence pointed to suicide, including a shrine-like arrangement of family pictures and a Bible in Castro's cell, an increasing tone of frustration in his prison journal and the reality of spending the rest of his life in prison while subject to constant harassment." The [[Ohio State Highway Patrol]] also reviewed the case and reached the same conclusion.<ref name="suiciderpt">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |title=Consultants: Kidnapper Ariel Castro's death a suicide |last=Welsh-Huggins |first1=Andrew |date=December 3, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206061146/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |archivedate=December 6, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

===Books=== <!-- Listed chronologically by release date --> *{{cite book |title=Dead Giveaway: The Rescue, Hamburgers, White Folks, and Instant Celebrity...What You Saw on TV Doesn't Begin to Tell the Story... |first=Charles |last=Ramsey |date=2014 |publisher=Gray & Company |location=Cleveland |isbn=1938441516 }} *{{cite book |title=[[Finding Me: A Decade of Darkness, a Life Reclaimed]]: a Memoir of the Cleveland Kidnappings |first1=Michelle |last1=Knight |first2=Michelle |last2=Burford |authorlink2=Michelle Burford<!-- Leave redlink --> |date=2014 |publisher=[[Weinstein Books]]|location=New York |isbn=1602862575 }} *{{cite book|title=Life After Darkness: Finding Healing and Happiness After the Cleveland Kidnappings|first=Michelle|last=Knight|date=2018|publisher=[[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette Books]]|location=Paris|isbn=1602865752}} *{{cite book |title=The Lost Girls: The True Story of the Cleveland Abductions and the Incredible Rescue of Michelle Knight, Amanda Berry, and Gina DeJesus |first=John |last=Glatt |authorlink=John Glatt |date=2015 |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]] |location=London |isbn=1250036364 }} *{{cite book |title=Hope: A Memoir of Survival in Cleveland |first1=Amanda |last1=Berry |first2=Gina |last2=DeJesus |first3=Mary |last3=Jordan |first4=Kevin |last4=Sullivan |authorlink3=Mary Jordan (journalist) |authorlink4=Kevin Sullivan (journalist) |date=2015 |publisher=[[Penguin Books|Penguin]]|location=London |isbn=0698178955 }}
===Films=== *{{cite AV media |year=2015 |title=[[Cleveland Abduction]]<!-- Leave as redlink to match redlink on Taryn Manning article --> |medium=[[television film]] |publisher=[[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] }}<ref>{{IMDb title|tt4262142|Cleveland Abduction}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/cleveland-abduction |title=Cleveland Abduction |publisher=Lifetime |access-date=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201044/http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/cleveland-abduction |archivedate=May 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Stockly |title=Saturday's TV Highlights and Weekend Talk: 'Cleveland Abduction' |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-saturdays-tv-highlights-and-weekend-talk-cleveland-abduction-20150501-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 1, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504012306/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-saturdays-tv-highlights-and-weekend-talk-cleveland-abduction-20150501-story.html |archivedate=May 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

{{notability|date=March 2011}} '''Batch 10''' is a name journalists have given to the tenth batch of former [[Saudi captives in Guantanamo|Saudi captives]] to be repatriated to [[Saudi Arabia]]n custody.<ref name=Bbc2010-10-13> {{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/newsnight/8454804.stm |title = Yemen al-Qaeda link to Guantanamo Bay prison |publisher = [[BBC News]] |date = 2010-01-13 |author = Peter Taylor |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Fprogrammes%2Fnewsnight%2F8454804.stm&date=2010-01-15 |archivedate = 2010-01-15 |quote = Mr Obama's dilemma is dramatically illustrated by a BBC investigation into what happened to the 14 detainees of Batch 10, who were flown home to Saudi Arabia just over two years ago. |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref><ref> {{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/saudiarabia/7105454/Recruits-seek-out-al-Qaedas-deadly-embrace-across-a-growing-arc-of-jihadist-terror.html | title=Recruits seek out al-Qaeda's deadly embrace across a growing arc of jihadist terror | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date=2010-01-31 | author1=Richard Spencer | author2=Adrian Blomfield | author3=Mike Pflanz | author4=Ben Farmer | author5=Colin Freeman | author6=Sean Rayment | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203060638/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/saudiarabia/7105454/Recruits-seek-out-al-Qaedas-deadly-embrace-across-a-growing-arc-of-jihadist-terror.html | archivedate=2010-02-03 | dead-url=yes | quote=The tenth group of Saudis to be flown back from Guantanamo Bay, no less than five of the original 14 who passed through the programme absconded to neighbouring Yemen to re-embrace terrorism. To the embarrassment of their mentors, and the dismay of Washington, one Batch 10 member, Said al-Shihri, has since re-surfaced as no less than deputy leader of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the movement’s new Yemen-based branch. The group opened up the latest frontier in the war on terror last month, when it claimed to have groomed the so-called Detroit “Underpants Bomber”, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab. | df= }}</ref><ref name=TheAge-2010-02-02> {{cite news | url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/alqaedas-new-world-order-20100201-n8vv.html | title=Al-Qaeda's new world order | publisher=[[The Age]] | date=2010-02-02 |author1=Richard Spencer |author2=Colin Freeman | accessdate=2010-04-19 | quote=With its swimming pool, games rooms and therapy courses such as '10 Steps Toward Positive Thinking', it resembles a jihadist's version of a mental health treatment clinic. Yet like any rehab program, it also has its recidivists - and 'batch 10', to which Bawardi belonged, is a case in point. }}</ref> Five of the fourteen captives in this group repatriated to Saudi captivity on November 9, 2007 were among the eleven former Guantanamo captives to be listed on the 85 men on the [[Saudi list of most wanted suspected terrorists]], published on February 3, 2009. One of the cohort, [[Said Ali al-Shihri]], became second in command of [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]].
According to [[Peter Taylor (journalist)|Peter Taylor]], reporting for the ''BBC'', his team found that the cohort of Saudis repatriated in November 2007 problematic.<ref name=Bbc2010-10-13/> He reported that many of these captives were not rehabilitated. He reported that five of the fourteen men in batch 10 escaped to [[Yemen]], and joined jihadists there. The version of the men's names were [[Mohammed al-Awfi]], [[Said al-Shihri]], [[Yussef al-Shihri]], [[Murtadha Ali Saeed Magram]] and [[Turki Meshawi Zayid al-Assiri]]. Said al-Shihri and Mohammed al-Awfi appeared in an alarming video in January 2009. Said al-Shihri took a leadership role in [[Al Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula]]. Yussef al-Shihri was killed in a shoot-out with Saudi security officials. He is alleged to have tried to cross the Saudi border dressed in a [[Burkha]], an all-encompassing female garment, armed with a suicide belt. Taylor reports that Murtadha Ali Saeed Magram and Turki Meshawi Zayid al-Assiri remain at large. The other nine men repatriated in batch 10 were: [[Zaid Muhamamd Sa'id Al Husayn]], [[Sultan Ahmed Dirdeer Musa Al Uwaydha]], [[Khalid Saud Abd Al Rahman Al Bawardi]], [[Faha Sultan]], [[Fahd Umr Abd Al Majid Al Sharif]], [[Nayif Abdallah Ibrahim Al Nukhaylan]], [[Abdullah Abd Al Mu'in Al Wafti]], [[Hani Saiid Mohammad Al Khalif]] and [[Jabir Hasan Muhamed Al Qahtani]].<ref name=ConsolidatedReleaseList> {{cite news | url=http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/09-F-0031_doc1.pdf | title=Consolidated chronological listing of GTMO detainees released, transferred or deceased | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | author=[[OARDEC]] | date=2008-10-09 | accessdate=2008-12-28 | quote= | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227004519/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/09-F-0031_doc1.pdf | archivedate=2008-12-27 | df= }} </ref><ref name=AsharqAlawsat2009-02-06> {{cite news |url=http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=15638 |title=A Clear Generation Gap in Saudi Most Wanted List |publisher=[[Asharq Alawsat]] |author=Mshari Al-Zaydi |date=2009-02-06 |accessdate=2009-02-06 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528050308/http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3 |archivedate=2010-05-28 |df= }} </ref>
==References== <references/>

#REDIRECT [[Nigel Hamilton (author)]]
[[Category:Biography (genre)]] [[Category:Historiography]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} The '''Bolton 7''' were a group of [[gay]] and [[bisexual]] men who were convicted on 12 January 1998 before Judge Michael Lever at [[Bolton]] Crown Court of the offences of gross indecency under the [[Sexual Offences Act 1956]] and of [[age of consent]] offences under the [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]]. Although [[Gay sexual practices|gay sex]] was partially decriminalised by the [[Sexual Offences Act 1967]], they were all convicted under section 13 of the 1956 Act because more than two men had sex together, which was still illegal. One of the participants (Craig Turner) was also six months under the statutory [[age of consent]] for [[Gay sexual practices|gay sex]] which was 18 at the time.
==Offences== Under the provisions of the 1967 Act, the [[age of consent]] for [[Gay sexual practices|gay sex]] was different from that of the [[heterosexual]] [[age of consent]] of 16, and had only been reduced from 21 to 18 by the [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]]. Equivalent [[heterosexual]] behaviour was not a crime.<ref name=Dearden1999 >{{Cite journal | last = Dearden | first = Nick | title = The Queen and the 'Bolton Seven' | journal = [[Feminist Legal Studies]] | volume = 7 | issue = 3 | pages = 317-332 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1023/A:1009218800557 | date = October 1999 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1023/A:1009218800557 | quote= This note examines the case of a group of gay men who, having engaged in consensual sexual acts together, became known as the `Bolton Seven’ following their conviction in 1998 for offences of buggery and/or gross indecency. More particularly the note scrutinises the implications of the ages of the participants (one of whom, at 17 , was unable to give lawful consent to sexual intercourse with a man) in the light of the enactment of Part I of the Sex Offenders Act 1997 which introduces a system of compulsory registration by some convicted and cautioned sex offenders with the police (including men convicted of, or cautioned for, buggery or gross indecency). The note explores the justification for inclusion of these offences within the remit of the 1997 Act together with the cultural construction of gay men as predatory and as constituting a risk to younger members of society. It also analyses some of the effects of the registration requirement in terms of it constituting a potential violation of fundamental rights such as equality and respect for private life. This discussion is located particularly within the context of the jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights and the introduction of the Human Rights Act 1998 in the U.K. | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
The offences only came to light after police seized videos of the men having sex, which they had filmed for their own personal use. All the men were either lovers, ex-boyfriends, or friends of friends.
==Sentences== During [[Sentence (law)|sentencing]] on 20 February 1998 Gary Abdie, David Godfrey, Mark Love and Jonathan Moore (all of whom were in their early 20s), and Craig Turner (17 at the time of the offences but 18 when he appeared in court) were given [[probation]] and [[community service]] orders. The Judge gave Norman Williams a two-year [[suspended sentence|suspended prison sentence]] and Terry Connell received a nine-month suspended sentence and was ordered to pay £500 towards the cost of the prosecution. Moore (20), Williams (33) and Connell (55) were also required to sign the Sex Offenders Register for the [[age of consent]] offences committed with Turner. Estimates of the overall cost of the prosecution were in the region of £500,000.
Despite their convictions, none of them received custodial sentences possibly as a result of a high-profile campaign led by gay [[human rights]] group [[OutRage!]]. Over 400 letters were presented to the court in support of the men including those from MPs, Bishops and [[human rights]] groups. The letters urged the judge not to impose a custodial sentence, with one group, [[Amnesty International]], pledging to declare the men prisoners of conscience should they be imprisoned.
==Aftermath== In 2000, six of the men appealed to the [[European Court of Human Rights]] arguing that the prosecutions against them had violated their rights under the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] by interfering with 'the right to respect for a private family life' enshrined in article 8 of the Convention. They were subsequently awarded compensation. As Williams was not part of the litigation, he was not deemed eligible by the Home Office for the compensation.
Legislation subsequently introduced by the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Government has broadly equalised the treatment of [[homosexual]] and [[heterosexual]] behaviours in criminal law. The [[Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 2000]] equalised the [[age of consent]] for [[Gay sexual practices|gay sex]] with that of the [[heterosexual]] [[age of consent]] which is now 16 for both. The [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]], though subject to some controversy, introduced an overhaul in the way sexual offences are dealt with by the police and courts, replacing provisions that date as far back to the 1956 legislation. The offences of gross indecency and [[buggery]] have been repealed and sexual activity between more than two men is no longer a [[crime in the United Kingdom]].
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.sodomylaws.org/world/united_kingdom/uknews01.htm Sodomy Laws - Bolton 7] *[http://www.outrage.org.uk OutRage! website] *[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/eur45/002/1998/en/ Amnesty Press Release - Bolton 7] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071227222456/http://www.gaymonitor.co.uk/bolton7.htm Gaymonitor - Appeal to ECHR]
[[Category:People convicted of sodomy]] [[Category:1990s in LGBT history]] [[Category:Sex scandals]] [[Category:English people convicted of child sexual abuse]] [[Category:LGBT history in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1998 in England]] [[Category:Gay history]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]]

[[File:Le Petit Journal - Chauffeurs.jpg|thumb|right|The ''Chauffeurs de la Drome'' torture a victim, ''[[Le Petit Journal (newspaper)|Le Petit Journal]]'', 15 November 1908]] The '''Chauffeurs de la Drome''' (The Heaters of Drome) was a gang of four French criminals who were responsible for a wave of [[theft]], [[torture]], and [[murder]] in the [[Departments of France|department]] of [[Drôme]] in southeast France during the early years of the twentieth century.
Three were [[execution|executed]] in September 1909; the fourth died at the [[penal colony]] on [[Devil's Island]], [[French Guiana]], where he had been sentenced to [[life imprisonment]].
==Criminal career== The four men were Octave-Louis David (b.1873), Pierre-Augustin-Louis Berruyer (b.1873), both shoemakers; Urban-Célestin Liottard (b.1863), a labourer, and Jean Lamarque.
David had a long criminal career and was claimed to be the ringleader. He had met Lamarque in prison, and through him met Berruyer. Beurruyer's house in [[Romans-sur-Isère]] was where Lamarque and the fourth man, Liottard, lived as boarders.<ref name="romanshistorique" />
The gang typically carried out [[home invasion]]s on remote, rural dwellings, where they tortured householders into revealing the locations of hidden valuables by burning their feet. This form of [[banditry]] was not unknown in France; criminals who did this were widely known as ''[[Chauffeur (criminal)|chauffeurs]] (heaters).<ref name="Anderson2011">{{cite book|author=Malcolm Anderson|title=In Thrall to Political Change: Police and Gendarmerie in France|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CYqKByxmueEC&pg=PA53|date=25 August 2011|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-969364-1|pages=53}}</ref>
The ''Chauffeurs de la Drome'' were responsible for as many as 18 murders between 1905 and 1908.<ref name="Anderson2011" /> They were able to avoid suspicion by maintaining their legitimate occupations during the day, carrying out attacks at night.
==Arrest, trial and execution== [[File:Execution of Liottard and Berruyer and David in 1909 2.jpg|thumb|right|David, the first to be executed, being led to the guillotine. Valence, 22 September 1909<ref name="Le carnet de l'abolition" />]] Berruyer was arrested on 22 October 1908 at his house; a search of the house revealed a large cache of stolen items. Liottard and David were arrested soon after but the fourth man, Lamarque, escaped. Their eight-day trial began at [[Valence, Drôme]] on 2 July 1909.<ref name="romanshistorique">{{cite web | url=http://www.romanshistorique.fr/romans-sur-isere-la-maison-des-chauffeurs-de-la-drome-rue-pecherie | title=La maison des Chauffeurs de la Drôme, rue Pêcherie | publisher=Romans Historique | language=French | date=26 May 2010 | access-date=15 August 2016}}</ref> All four men were convicted and sentenced to death. [[Armand Fallières]], the [[President of France]] at the time, was personally opposed to the [[death penalty]], but the strength of public opinion made it impossible for him to accept their pleas for [[clemency]].
The executions by [[guillotine]] of David, Berruyer and Liottard took place at Valence, Drôme, on 22 September 1909<ref name="Histoires de bourreaux" /> at 6 am, within the space of a few minutes and before a cheering crowd. A number of photographs were taken despite this being against the law; postcards were widely sold, and there were newspaper advertisements for public showings of motion pictures of the executions.<ref name="Histoires de bourreaux">{{cite web | url=https://histoiresdebourreaux.blogspot.co.uk/2009/09/22-septembre-1909-lexecution-des.html | title=Histoires de bourreaux |trans-title=| language=French | date=22 September 2009 | access-date=15 August 2016}}</ref>
Lamarque was captured in 1910. He had been sentenced to death [[''in absentia'']], but after his capture his sentence was commuted to life imprisonment with [[hard labour]] in the penal colony at [[Devil's Island]].<ref name="Le carnet de l'abolition">{{cite web | url=http://abolition.hypotheses.org/796 | title=Quatorze photos pour une exécution | language=French | publisher=Le carnet de l'abolition | date=10 September 2012 | access-date=15 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}}
[[Category:People executed by France by decapitation]] [[Category:French people convicted of murder]] [[Category:1909 deaths]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]]

{{cleanup-reorganize|date=December 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2015}}
A '''Ciguapa''' (pronounced see-GWAH-pah) is a mythological creature of [[Dominican Republic|Dominican]] and [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] folklore. They are commonly described as having human female form with brown or dark blue skin, backward facing feet, and very long manes of smooth, glossy hair that covers their otherwise naked bodies. They supposedly inhabit the high mountains of the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico.
== Overview == These creatures have nocturnal habits. Also, due to the position of their feet, one can never quite tell from which direction the beings are moving from by looking at their footprints. Some people believe that they bring death, and it is said that one should not look them in the eye,<ref>{{cite news | author=Liza Phoenix| url=http://www.lizaphoenix.com/encyclopedia/ciguapa.shtml| title= Ciguapa| publisher= lizaphoenix| date=2007-03-05 | accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref> otherwise the person is at risk of being bewitched permanently. Also, the only vocalization made by ciguapas is said to be a kind of whine or chirping.
Ciguapas are considered to be magical beings, beautiful in appearance to some, yet horrendous to others. All sources agree that they are wild creatures. They are compared in many cases to mermaids: beautiful yet cruel, and far from innocent. Deceitful and ready to capture the wayward traveler, they are said that they are so beautiful as to lure men into the forest, even though following footprints is misleading, to make love with them only to kill them afterwards. Even today, one can still find inhabitants who confirm having sighted a ciguapa.
Lore states that the only way to capture a ciguapa is by tracking them at night, during a [[full moon]], with a black and white [[polydactylic]] dog (called ''cinqueño'' dog).<ref>http://mipais.jmarcano.com/cultura/mitos/ciguapa.html</ref>
Though many believe that the myth of the ciguapa is of [[Taíno people|Taino]] origin, it has been argued that is probably of more recent concoction, being possibly attributed to African beliefs brought to the island by enslaved peoples during the colonial period. More to the point, no known Taino artifacts or lore make reference to any creature even remotely similar to it.<ref>http://mipais.jmarcano.com/cultura/mitos/ciguapa.html</ref> Also, the legend may have originated from other myths, as distant as the [[Guarani people|Guaraní]] ''Curupí'' or the [[Hindu]] [[Churel]], which was described by [[Rudyard Kipling]] in ''My Own True Ghost Story'' as having traits amazingly similar to those of the ciguapa. Nonetheless, the Hindu hypothesis may be far-fetched since there is no way to ascertain how this story got to the Dominican Republic during the nineteenth century, when no cultural exchange whatsoever occurred between these nations.
A Dominican film called "''El Mito de la Ciguapa''" (The Myth of the Ciguapa) is set to be produced by [[Xenda Films]].
==See also== *[[Sihuanaba]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.lizaphoenix.com/encyclopedia/ciguapa.shtml The Phoenixian Book of Creatures] * [http://www.cuco.com.ar/ciguapa.htm DICCIONARIO DE MITOS Y LEYENDAS] * [http://mipais.jmarcano.com/cultura/mitos/ciguapa.html ''La Ciguapa'' by J.E. Marcano]

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Marian_Cross#Coat_of_Arms_of_Pope_John_Paul_II]] {{R to section}} [[Category:Pope John Paul II|Coat of arms]] [[Category:Personal coats of arms|John Paul II]]

{{expand Swedish|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Greater coat of arms of the Kingdom of Sweden |country = Sweden |image = Great coat of arms of Sweden.svg |image_width = 230 |middle = Great coat of arms of Sweden (without mantle).svg |middle_width = 180px |middle_caption = Version without the ermine mantling |lesser = Great coat of arms of Sweden (shield and chain).svg |lesser_width = 120 |lesser_caption = Version without the ermine mantling, the compartment and the supporters |image2 = Great coat of arms of Sweden (shield).svg |image2_width = 75 |image2_caption = Version consisting of the crowned escutcheon only |armiger = [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf]]
[[King of Sweden|The King of Sweden]] |year_adopted = 1448
November 17, 1905 |supporters = two lions regardant, crowned and with forked tails (queue fourchée) Or armed gules, standing on a compartment Or |shield = Azure, quartered by a cross Or with outbent arms, and an inescutcheon containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three open crowns Or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams argent, a lion crowned with an open crown Or armed gules. The inescutcheon is party per pale the arms for the House of Vasa (Bendwise azure, argent and gules, a vasa (sheaf of wheat) Or); and the House of Bernadotte (Azure, issuant from a wavy base a bridge with three arches and two towers embattled argent, in honour point an eagle regardant with wings inverted resting on thunderbolts Or, and in chief the Big Dipper constellation of the same). |crest = Royal Crown of Sweden |orders = [[Order of Seraphim]] |compartment = Pedestal Or |other_elements = All surrounded by ermine mantling, crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseladorned strings Or |earlier_versions = |use = }} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Lesser coat of arms of the Kingdom of Sweden |country = Sweden |image = Coat of arms of Sweden (shield and chain).svg |image_width = 120 |lesser = Coat of arms of Sweden.svg |lesser_width = 75 |lesser_caption = Version without the Order of the Seraphim |armiger = The [[Riksdag]]
[[Government of Sweden]]
[[King of Sweden]] |year_adopted = 1336{{cite journal |last=Loÿe |first=Georges de |title=Om ursprunget till det svenska riksvapnet Tre Kronor |year=1986 |journal=Heraldisk tidsskrift |volume=1986 |issue=6 |pages=54, 155–174 : ill. |id=0440-6966 |issn=0440-6966 |language=sv}}
November 17, 1905 |shield = Azure, three coronets Or, placed two above one |crest = Royal Crown of Sweden |orders = [[Order of Seraphim]] |use = }} The '''coat of arms of the [[Kingdom of Sweden]]''' ({{lang-sv|Sveriges riksvapen}}) has a lesser and a greater version. == Regulated usage == The usage of the coats of arms is regulated by Swedish Law, [[Swedish Code of Statutes|Act]] [http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/19700498.HTM 1970:498], which states (in unofficial translation) that "in commercial activities, the coats of arms, the flag or other official insignia of Sweden may not be used in a trademark or other insignias for products or services without proper authorisation. This includes any mark or text referring to the Swedish State which this can give the commercial mark a sign of official endorsement. This includes municipal coats of arms which are registered." Any representation consisting of three crowns ordered two above one are considered to be the lesser coat of arms, and its usage is therefore restricted by law 1970:498. ==Variants== The arms of Sweden were first formally codified by law in 1908.{{cite web|url=http://runeberg.org/rikskal/1909/0002.html|title=i (Svensk rikskalender / 1909)|website=Runeberg.org|accessdate=9 January 2018}} This law also formally codifies the differences between the "greater" and "lesser" arms. The present law prescribing the two arms dates from 1982. ===Greater version=== The greater coat of arms is blazoned in Swedish law as follows:
''A shield [[azure (heraldry)|azure]], quartered by a cross [[Or (heraldry)|Or]] with outbent arms, and an [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|inescutcheon]] containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three [[Crown (heraldry)|open crowns]] Or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams [[argent]], a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] crowned with an open crown Or armed [[gules]]. The inescutcheon is [[Division of the field|party per pale]] the arms for the [[House of Vasa]] (Bendwise azure, argent and gules, a ''vasa'' Or); and the [[House of Bernadotte]] (Azure, issuant from a wavy base a bridge with three arches and two towers embattled argent, in honor point an eagle regardant with wings inverted resting on thunderbolts Or, and in chief the Big Dipper constellation of the same). The main shield is crowned by a royal crown and surrounded by the insignia of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]. [[Supporters|Supported]] by two lions regardant, crowned and with forked tails Or armed gules, standing on a [[Compartment (heraldry)|compartment]] Or. All surrounded by [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] mantling, crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseladorned strings Or.''Original text of Swedish statute 1982:268, 2 §, states: ''Stora riksvapnet utgörs av en blå huvudsköld, kvadrerad genom ett kors av guld med utböjda armar, samt en hjärtsköld som innehåller det kungliga husets dynastivapen. Huvudsköldens första och fjärde fält innehåller tre öppna kronor av guld, ordnade två över en. Huvudsköldens andra och tredje fält innehåller tre ginbalksvis gående strömmar av silver, överlagda med ett upprest, med öppen krona krönt lejon av guld med röd tunga samt röda tänder och klor. Hjärtskölden är kluven. Första fältet innehåller Vasaättens vapen: ett i blått, silver och rött styckat fält, belagt med en vase av guld. Andra fältet innehåller ätten Bernadottes vapen: i blått fält en ur vatten uppskjutande bro med tre valv och två krenelerade torn, allt av silver, däröver en örn av guld med vänstervänt huvud och sänkta vingar gripande om en åskvigg av guld samt överst Karlavagnens stjärnbild av guld. Huvudskölden är krönt med en kunglig krona och omges av Serafimer ordens insignier. Sköldhållare är två tillbakaseende, med kunglig krona krönta lejon med kluvna svansar samt röda tungor, tänder och klor. Lejonen står på ett postament av guld. Det hela omges av en med kunglig krona krönt hermelinsfodrad vapenmantel av purpur med frans av guld och uppknuten med tofsprydda snören av guld. Stora riksvapnet får brukas även utan ordensinsignier, sköldhållare, postament eller vapenmantel.'' {{cite web |url= http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/19820268.HTM |title= Lag (1982:268) om Sveriges riksvapen |accessdate=2008-06-27 |work= Swedish Code of Statutes |publisher= [[Sveriges Riksdag]] |date= 1982-04-29 |language= Swedish}}
The greater arms may also be displayed only with the crowned escutcheon. While the arms have undergone significant changes over the years, such as changing the inescutcheon with the ruling dynasty, they are based on arms created by King [[Charles VIII of Sweden|Karl Knutsson]] in 1448.{{cite web |url= http://www.riksarkivet.se/default.aspx?id=1268&ptid=0 |title= Stora riksvapnet |language= Swedish |publisher= Swedish National Archives |date= 2011-12-20 |accessdate=2012-01-29}} The [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] used in the greater blazon has in total five elements: 4 [[Quartering (heraldry)|quarterings]] on the main escutcheon (two coats of arms duplicated), and three coat of arms incorporated into an escutcheon of pretense. However, Bernadotte never used any stars in the arms of Pontecorvo (neither as Prince of Pontecorvo, nor as King of Sweden and Norway). The stars were introduced as an element in the royal coat of arms in the 19th century,{{cite book |last=Berghman |first=Arvid |title=Dynastien Bernadottes vapen och det svenska riksvapnet |series=Skrifter / utgivna av Riksheraldikerämbetet, 99-2298099-1 ; 1 |year=1944 |publisher=Svensk litteratur |location=Stockholm |language=sv}} chosen as a symbol of Sweden's eternal existence, as in the poem by [[Esaias Tegnér]]: {{quote|As long as [[Charles's Wain]] still turns, Its golden wheels around the Northern zone, As long as the land still produces iron and heroes, Intact shall stand the ancient Swedish throne.}} This symbol became especially popular through its allusion to the name that had been borne by so many famous Swedish kings. [[Ursa Major]], or as it is called in Swedish, ''Karlavagnen'' (Charles' Wain), adds a Swedish accent to the Bernadotte dynastic coat of arms much in the same way as do the Vasa arms.{{cite web|url=http://www.theheraldrysociety.com/articles/early_history_of_heraldry/the_three_crowns_of_sweden.htm|title=The Heraldry Society|website=Theheraldrysociety.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} {{familytree/start |White box with three children Red box, Green box, Blue box, all married to each other}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |finish| | | | |finish=[[File:Great shield of arms of Sweden.svg|120px]]}} {{familytree|border=0| |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| }} {{familytree|border=0|CROWN| |BJELB| |BERN |CROWN=[[File:Shield of arms of Sweden.svg|120px]]
The [[three Crowns|three crowns]]|BJELB=[[File:Arms of Bjelbo.svg|120px]]
[[House of Bjelbo]]|BERN=[[File:Arms of Bernadotte.svg|120px]]
[[House of Bernadotte]]}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | | | | |,|-|'| }} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |VASA|^|PONT |VASA=[[File:Arms of Vasa.svg|120px]]
The [[House of Vasa]]|PONT=[[File:Coat of Arms of Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte.svg|150x150px]]
Arms of [[Charles XIV John of Sweden|Jean Baptiste Jules Bernadotte]]
as prince of [[Ponte Corvo]]
and [[Marshal of France]]
(later Charles XIV of Sweden)}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | | | | |,|-|'| }} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |VASA|^|PONT |VASA=[[File:Arms of the French Empire3.svg|120px]]
[[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]]|PONT=
[[Ponte Corvo]]}} {{familytree/end}} [[File:Personal command-sign of the King of Sweden.svg|thumb|left|The personal command sign, for military use, of the King is a rendition of the emblazonment of the greater arms. Introduced by royal regulation in 1943, it has only been created once.]] The arms are supported by two lions with forked tails (''queue fourchée''), facing away from the shield and crowned with Royal Crowns. For centuries, the lion has been an important element in Swedish heraldry and especially for the State Coat of Arms. The shield may be surmounted by the Collar of the [[Order of Seraphim]], the foremost order in Sweden, and the highest honour the Swedish state can bestow on an individual.See sections 2 and 3, Lag No. 268 om Sveriges Riksvapen of April 29, 1982. Besides being the official national coat of arms, the greater coat of arms is also the personal coat of arms of the king, and as such he can decree its use as a personal coat of arms by other members of the [[House of Bernadotte|Royal House]], with the alterations and additions decided by him. [[Blazon]]: "The greater state arms consist of a head shield azure, quartered by a cross or with outbent arms, and an [[inescutcheon]] containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three coronets or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams argent, a lion crowned with an open crown or with armaments gules. The inescutcheon is party per pale the arms for the [[House of Vasa]] and the [[House of Bernadotte]]. The main shield is crowned by a royal crown and surrounded by the insignia of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]. Supported by two lions regardant or crowned, with parted tails and armaments gules, standing on a postament. All surrounded by hermine mantling crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseled strings or." ===Lesser version=== The lesser coat of arms is mainly used by the [[Government of Sweden]] and subordinate government authorities. As such it may be joined by insignias symbolising the activity of individual government agencies, following approval by the State Board of Heraldry. It is, for instance, embroidered on all [[Swedish police]] uniforms and in various coats of arms of the [[Swedish Armed Forces]]. Blazon: "Azure, with three coronets Or, ordered two above one." Crowned with a royal crown. The shield may also be surrounded by the insignias of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]." ===Royal Family=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Coat of arms !! Bearer |- style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Great coat of arms of Sweden.svg|170px]] || [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden]] |- style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Greater coat of arms of Silvia, Queen of Sweden.svg|170px]] || [[Queen Silvia of Sweden|Silvia, Queen of Sweden]] |- style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Coat of arms of Crown Princess Victoria, Duchess of Västergötland.svg|120px]] || [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|Crown Princess Victoria, Duchess of Västergötland]] |- style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Coat of arms of Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland.svg|120px]] || [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Princess Estelle, Duchess of Östergötland.svg|120px]]|| [[Princess Estelle, Duchess of Östergötland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Oscar Duke of Skåne.svg|120px]]|| [[Prince Oscar, Duke of Skåne]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland.svg|120px]]|| [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Alexander, Duke of Södermanland.svg|120px]]||[[Prince Alexander, Duke of Södermanland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland.svg|120px]]|| [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Princess Leonore, Duchess of Gutland.svg|120px]]||[[Princess Leonore, Duchess of Gotland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Nicolas, Duke of Ångermanland.svg|120px]]||[[Prince Nicolas, Duke of Ångermanland]] |} == See also == {{commons|Coat of arms of Sweden}} *[[Swedish heraldry]] *[[Three Crowns]] *[[Flag of Sweden]] *[[List of flags of Sweden]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{National Symbols of Sweden}} {{Sweden topics}} {{Coats of arms of Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coat Of Arms Of Sweden}}
